title: How come players can run it down without getting banned?
body:
Is it not punishable? It is obviously against the rules but these players never get punished or banned. They don't get muted becuase they dont type anything and Riot has no one looking at games. People can run it down unpunished forever.

Can we get a player review system like CSGO's overwatch?

replies.body:
> It is obviously against the rules but these players never get punished or banned.

Yes they do.

There was a high profile case of a streamer getting banned for trolling his teammates not a month ago.

The issue is is that it's significantly harder to tell when people are *actually* intentionally feeding or trolling (aside from super obvious cases) or if they are simply having a bad game or actually unskilled. Riot has to err on the side of caution to not punish people that are innocent.

When a case of trolling or feeding is verified to be accurate, then it is an instant 14 day ban, as opposed to chat toxicity, which has two chat restrictions first before any bans.

If you are permanently banned, **Riot does not want you to come back.**

End of story. 

They do not want your money. They don't want your business. They don't want anything to do with you. 

They just want you gone, and a permanent ban is the way of showing that.

Tell me a feasible way to prevent someone from making a new account. Keep in mind it needs to be legal for those under 18, as 13 is the "minimum" age req. It also needs to not cause collateral damage for shared computers.
Please, show me this endorsement. I've never seen it, so if you can provide evidence, I'd be happy to change my comment.

Riot did not continue to let him play. In fact, any account that was identified as his was instantly permanently banned.

However, once it was shown that he had actually changed his behavior, they lifted that **ID Ban**, and allow him to make a *new* account. None of his old accounts were restored.

If you can actually change, Riot has no problem with that. However, the vast majority of people who have received a permanent ban a) do not come back, and b) have no interest in reforming their behavior.

> How did he prove that he had reformed.. without playing?

Because there is no way to actually flat-out prevent someone from playing a Free-to-Play game that only requires a free email address and nearly any computer to sign up and play.

Any accounts that were identified to be his were instantly banned. His behavior on those accounts was audited, and it showed signs of changes away from toxicity, and so at a certain point, his ID ban was lifted.

As for "more revenue/free advertising for them", him being essentially an advertisement for their game was one of the major factors that lead to his ID ban, as having a figure who promoted himself as being toxic and having a lot of permanent bans connected to your game is not a good appearance.
 ---
Not being able to stop toxic people from playing **DOES NOT** equal an endorsement of toxicity. I cannot stop murder from happening. Does that mean I endorse murder?

> Endorse (Verb) - 
#to _**express support or approval**_ of someone or something

Again:

#Not being able to stop something *DOES NOT* mean they approve of that thing happening.

Endorsement requires support. Non-action from inability to prevent does not mean an endorsement has occurred.
